frame: Fat women cannot have eating disorders.

sample_rationales: By denying that fat women can have eating disorders, the frame dismisses and minimizes their suffering and well-being, showing a lack of empathy and concern for their harm.
The frame dismisses and minimizes the suffering of fat women with eating disorders, showing a lack of sensitivity to their well-being and mental health struggles.
The frame trivializes and dismisses the seriousness of eating disorders in fat women, showing insensitivity to their suffering and denying them concern and care.
The frame creates an unequal standard by excluding fat women from experiencing eating disorders, thus denying them equal recognition and treatment compared to other women.
By asserting that fat women cannot have eating disorders, the statement denies them equal recognition and treatment in health discourse based solely on body size.
By asserting that fat women cannot have eating disorders, the frame treats them unequally, denying them equal recognition and validation of mental health issues compared to others.
This statement shames fat women by mocking their bodies and suggesting they are morally deficient, reinforcing a sense of dishonor and social stigma.
The frame reinforces shame and stigma against fat women, damaging their dignity and treating them as dishonorable if they claim to have eating disorders.

values.rationale: By denying that fat women can have eating disorders, the frame dismisses and minimizes their suffering and well-being, showing a lack of empathy and concern for their harm.
The frame creates an unequal standard by excluding fat women from experiencing eating disorders, thus denying them equal recognition and treatment compared to other women.
Labeling fat women as incapable of eating disorders implies a view of their bodies as impure or inherently flawed, portraying them as degraded and unworthy of legitimate health concerns.
This statement shames fat women by mocking their bodies and suggesting they are morally deficient, reinforcing a sense of dishonor and social stigma.
The frame dismisses and minimizes the suffering of fat women with eating disorders, showing a lack of sensitivity to their well-being and mental health struggles.
By asserting that fat women cannot have eating disorders, the statement denies them equal recognition and treatment in health discourse based solely on body size.
The frame silences and marginalizes fat women’s voices and experiences of eating disorders, effectively restricting their freedom to be acknowledged as individuals with valid health concerns.
The frame trivializes and dismisses the seriousness of eating disorders in fat women, showing insensitivity to their suffering and denying them concern and care.
By asserting that fat women cannot have eating disorders, the frame treats them unequally, denying them equal recognition and validation of mental health issues compared to others.
This statement imposes a limiting stereotype on fat women, silencing their experiences and exerting oppressive control over their identity and health narratives.
The frame reinforces shame and stigma against fat women, damaging their dignity and treating them as dishonorable if they claim to have eating disorders.

frame: Anorexia is not a serious condition and can be used as a derogatory term.

sample_rationales: Trivializing anorexia dismisses the serious suffering of individuals with eating disorders, showing insensitivity to their harm and well-being.
The frame dismisses the serious suffering and well-being of individuals with eating disorders, reflecting insensitivity to harm and a lack of concern for their mental health.

The frame dismisses the seriousness of anorexia, downplaying the suffering and harm experienced by those with eating disorders, which violates the care foundation by showing insensitivity to others’ well-being.
Using a mental health condition as an insult marginalizes those affected, treating them unequally and reinforcing discriminatory attitudes.
By trivializing anorexia and using it as a derogatory label, the frame promotes unequal treatment and marginalization of those affected by eating disorders.
Employing anorexia as a derogatory term degrades individuals with the condition, undermining their dignity and purity of experience.

Trivializing a serious mental health condition degrades the inherent value of those suffering from anorexia, treating their experiences as impure or unworthy of respect, which violates the sanctity foundation.

values.rationale: Trivializing anorexia dismisses the serious suffering of individuals with eating disorders, showing insensitivity to their harm and well-being.
Using a mental health condition as an insult marginalizes those affected, treating them unequally and reinforcing discriminatory attitudes.
Employing anorexia as a derogatory term degrades individuals with the condition, undermining their dignity and purity of experience.

By trivializing anorexia and using it as a derogatory label, the frame promotes unequal treatment and marginalization of those affected by eating disorders.
Using anorexia as a derogatory term stigmatizes and shames individuals with this condition, undermining their dignity and social standing.

The frame dismisses the seriousness of anorexia, downplaying the suffering and harm experienced by those with eating disorders, which violates the care foundation by showing insensitivity to others’ well-being.
Using anorexia as a derogatory term attacks individuals’ dignity and reputation, shaming those affected and violating the honor foundation by inflicting social dishonor and stigma.

Trivializing a serious mental health condition degrades the inherent value of those suffering from anorexia, treating their experiences as impure or unworthy of respect, which violates the sanctity foundation.
